text: hello hi everyone profit Hannah here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of this new Mac
DeMarco album of five easy hot dogs this
is the latest full-length LP from one of
the chillest singers and songwriters on
the Indie circuit today Mr Mac DeMarco
who is pretty much a vet in the game at
this point but nonetheless seems uh not
so content to just rest on his Laurels
or simply pump out what is expected of
him by like the festival crowd that was
made clear in the Progressive maturation
of his songwriting uh from two all the
way up until this old dog but then he
switched things up pretty significantly
on 2019's here comes the cowboy which
had its catchier highlights but
simultaneously uh dropped tracks that
were a little experimental for him in
that they were super repetitive like the
intro cut or very very very stripped
back like in the case of heart to heart
as well as preoccupied then there were
also songs on this record that were just
unrepentant goofy such as choo choo I do
commend him for trying some new things
on this record even if a lot of it
didn't necessarily pan out and many fans
regard this album to be Mack's worst
thus far Mack is also trying something
new on five easy hot dogs as well as
this thing's an instrumental album kind
of framed in reaction to some artistic
restlessness that Mac was experiencing
during the pandemic which could be
fertile ground for some cool new ideas I
guess I've always appreciated these
subtle subtle flashes of Genius in Max
guitar work or some of his Melodies that
have showcased that I think he has a
firmer grasp of Music Theory than some
in his Lane maybe on an instrumental
record Mac will be incentivized to I
don't know show off some chaps since
he's basically leaving open all this
space where there might have been a tune
or a vocal otherwise or at least you
could hope because five easy hot dogs
isn't really that in fact it's kind of
what you could already imagine and
instrumental Mac DeMarco album to be if
he went about it in the most predictable
way possible which is funny but also
kind of sad in that I don't think anyone
saw an instrumental album coming from
Mac DeMarco but this record pretty much
sounds like what you would get if you
stripped the vocals out of any number of
his uh previously written and recorded
tracks which might have not been a bad
thing given that previously popular
tracks such as my kind of woman oh to
Viceroy as well as salad days I'll have
super standout and sticky guitar work
but many of the instrumentals on hot
dogs lack even that such as the song
Vancouver 3 which Cycles through these
really mind-numbing arpeggios with
little in the way of any musical
development for almost three minutes
it's not terrible it's not offensive but
it's not really gripping or interesting
either there are some Breezy but melodic
highlights on Cuts such as Gualala and
Gualala 2. the former has these cute
staccato little synth Melodies that
contrast with these sort of enchanting
two chord past messages the guitars in
which feel kind of warped and dreamy in
the way that a lot of Max guitars do the
latter of these two tracks features a
very similar formula but this time
around the chords and Melodies are much
moodier and even more subtly psychedelic
but not every instrumental on this LP is
as eventful comparatively like the
slowly swelling synth notes on Crescent
City for example aren't really
interesting or active enough to take up
the spotlight position they occupy then
the kind of melty gentle but discordant
notes that pile on top of each other on
what I guess is the chorus to Portland
yeah that's about the only thing about
that track that makes it sound distinct
Portland 2 I found to be much better
with a lot of very nuanced details that
you might miss if you're not paying
attention some of the inner workings of
the Slick guitar licks on this track
along with the harmonized woodwinds and
what sounds like some uh metallic or
electronic glitches popping up in the
background too I wish the track
developed more across its run time
because it mostly feels like a loop but
I said suppose it's fine while it's on
the instrumental variety continues onto
the track Victoria with what sounds like
some ghostly vibraphone something along
those lines playing and ringing out into
Oblivion though the tones start to sound
kind of awful as they shift around
sloppily over the two chords in the B
section of the song The Rhythm Section
is pretty stiff and leaves a lot to be
desired too which is kind of the same
problem with Vancouver too where the
guitar work is underscored by what
sounds like some very awkwardly played
claves which I hope you enjoy the sound
of because uh from here they make a lot
of reappearances on the record they make
for some strange Ambiance on the track
Vancouver 2 really most of the songs
that have a gentler approach where they
don't really seem to complement the
surrounding instrumentation they barely
fit into the composition on Edmonton but
they are thrown in anyway and they also
don't bring anything to the track
Chicago which is already pretty packed
with drums I love how this one
instrument barely fits on so many of
these tracks and just at one point in
the track list Max starts just throwing
them in just about everywhere I mean
really they do ruin some of these Cuts
but even if they weren't there this
record is still kind of riddled with
issues as I don't find the instrumentals
to be particularly inspired these tracks
are somehow even more wallpaper than I
have previously charged some of Max
Music to be I feel like this record is
essentially what you would get if Mac
DeMarco were tasked with coming out with
a series of just like you know chill
Lo-Fi study beats but you know in in his
style these cuts are tedious they are
absolutely drab and forgettable to the
point where it is unforgivable I'm
feeling a strong three on this one
